journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Design and analysis of compound potential energy regeneration system for hybrid hydraulic excavator

contrib-group.aff: The State Key Laboratory of Fluid Power Transmission and Control, Zhejiang University, China

author-notes.corresp: Tao Wang, The State Key Laboratory of Fluid Power Transmission and Control, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310027, China. Email: twang001@126.com

abstract.p: Potential energy regeneration system, which shares an electrical energy storage device with power system, can further improve the fuel economy of hybrid construction machinery without much additional expense. However, the conventional potential energy regeneration system also results in poorer dynamic performance of actuators in comparison to throttle-governing system. In addition, the capacity of the regenerator should be large enough to avoid overload. Based on comprehensive consideration, this article presents a compound potential energy regeneration system that combines the regeneration device and throttle together. The regenerative torque is adaptive to load so as to keep the pressure drop over the throttle almost constant, and then the actuator can be governed by adjusting the opening of the throttle. The compound potential energy regeneration system is analyzed and evaluated using the frequency domain method and nonlinear simulation. Finally, experiments under different parameter conditions are carried out, and some useful design reference is provided. The simulation and experimental results show the effectiveness of the designed system as well as its control strategy.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In recent years, energy crisis and environment pollution have become serious problems in the world range. It is meaningful to investigate the energy saving of construction machinery, especially excavators due to their wide application with extremely low efficiency. An energy audit of hydraulic excavators shows that over 40% of the energy consumption is dissipated in throttles in typical executing cycles.1 To reduce fuel consumption and heat productivity, regeneration is an attractive way that can be realized when booms are lowered down and large amount of potential energy is released.

Some potential energy regeneration systems (PERSs) have been proposed and implemented in hydraulic equipments, which suffer overrunning loads. A direct and economic approach is using a hydraulic accumulator.2 Bruun3 presented a PERS based on hydraulic accumulators and applied it to a 50 ton hydraulic excavator. The potential energy was converted into hydraulic form and stored in the accumulators when booms were lowered down and reutilized when booms were lifted up. Researchers including Virvalo, Liang, and Sun4–7 evaluated the energy savings in hydraulic cranes with different configurations of PERS such as accumulator-balancing cylinder and accumulator–pump–motor system. Accumulators were also considered as energy storage devices of PERS in elevators,8 forklifts,9 and drilling rig.10

Another well-known regeneration approach is to use electric energy storage devices such as batteries or super capacitors. Considering the cost of the recovered energy, this approach is often employed by the machines where the storage devices already exist such as electrical forklift. Andersen et al.11 developed a forklift with PERS where the hydraulic cylinder was directly driven by electric servomotor and hydraulic pump. Compared with the conventional machine, the efficiency was increased from 56% to 74% at high velocity and from 39% to 69% at low velocity. Minav et al.12,13 researched a similar system and evaluated the efficiencies of critical components.

Hybrid hydraulic excavators (HHEs) have received wide attention recently due to their energy-saving potential.14–17 For an electric hybrid power-driven excavator, an electrical PERS can be chosen simply because this machine is already equipped with an electric storage device. The concept of electrical regeneration for HHE has been proposed using an separate regeneration device installed in the return oil lines.18,19 However, different from the forklift, the excavator generally has a one-pump multiactuator structure and requires a high control performance for actuator operation. Therefore, the introduction of PERS usually brings in some additional effect, especially on the operability.20

This article aims to design a novel PERS that is optimal for HHE, considering comprehensive performance. The article is organized as follows. First, the main shortcomings of the conventional PERS are analyzed after introducing the basic structure. Second, the principle of the compound PERS is proposed, and three control strategies are discussed using frequency domain analysis. Third, simulations are carried out to evaluate the dynamic performances of different systems for comparison. Finally, the designed system and the optimal control strategy are validated by experimental results.

sec.title: System description
sec.p: Figure 1 shows the configuration of the studied HHE with a boom PERS. Similar with hybrid vehicles, the power source is composed of an electric machine and a diesel engine. The electric machine assists the engine in heavy load operation and absorbs the surplus energy of the engine in light load operation, according to a power management strategy. Thus, the engine can be operated in a high-efficiency region, and the fuel consumption is reduced.14 The hydraulic swing motor is replaced with an electrical motor that can be used to regenerate braking kinetic energy. The PERS mainly includes a directional valve, a controllable electric generator, and a hydraulic motor. In the conventional regeneration mode, when a boom is being lowered down, the corresponding directional valve is opened totally, and the potential energy of the boom is converted into electrical form and stored in the super capacitor. The lowering velocity of the actuator is indirectly governed by controlling the rotational speed of the generator.

caption.p: Configuration of hybrid hydraulic excavator with a boom PERS.

sec.title: Disadvantages of conventional PERS
sec.p: Although throttle losses are eliminated in the conventional PERS, there are two disadvantages impelling us to reconsider the system and develop more effective scheme. First, high control performance that is required in the operation of excavators is difficult to achieve due to the change of control mode. Second, the capacity of the regenerator should be designed according to the peak value of recoverable power; however, it cannot be fully used most of the time of operation and requires larger volume and more cost.

The details of the disadvantages will be described herein. Figure 2(a) and (b) shows the simplified schematic diagrams of the throttle-governing system without regeneration and the conventional PERS, respectively. To analyze the systems with mathematical tools, some assumptions are made as follows.

caption.p: Comparison of schematic diagrams: (a) without PERS and (b) conventional PERS.

list-item.p: The study concentrates on the lowering process in air where potential energy can be regenerated. The lifting process and the digging mode are not considered.
The effects of auxiliary valves such as safety valve, makeup valve, and holding valve are neglected.
The visual feedback of drivers is not considered when investigating the response of actuators to the control signals transferred from joysticks.
The pressure in the oil tank and the pressure in the small chamber of the hydraulic cylinder are approximated as zero.
The electrical dynamics of the generator is neglected, as the electrical response time is much smaller than the mechanical response time.
The variation of hydraulic chamber volume is not considered for simplification.
The kinematic relationship of boom mechanism is not considered, and the load mass is assumed to be constant.

sec.p: As shown in Figure 2, the system without regeneration is modeled first. The load dynamics of the single-rod hydraulic cylinder can be given as

where G is the load gravity on the rod, P1 is the pressure in the large chamber of the cylinder, A is the piston area, mc is the equivalent mass of the load, vc is the velocity of the rod, Bc is the viscous friction coefficient, and fc is the Coulomb friction force. The pressure dynamics of the loaded chamber can be given as

where Qt is the flow rate through the throttle, V1 is the volume of the loaded chamber, β is the bulk modulus of hydraulic oil, and C1 is the total leakage coefficient of the loaded chamber. The linear flow equation of the throttle can be expressed as
where Kx is the flow gain, x is the spool position, and Kp is the flow pressure coefficient.
By taking the Laplace transformation and solving the equation sets, the following function is given
In general, Bc is sufficiently small to be neglected. As a standard two-order transfer function expressed in equation (4), the natural frequency and the damping ratio can be given respectively as
For the conventional PERS, the load dynamics is the same as in the system without regeneration. The pressure dynamics of the loaded chamber can be rewritten as
where Qm is the flow rate through the hydraulic motor and can be expressed as
where ωm is the rotational speed and Dm is the displacement of the hydraulic motor.
Similarly, the Laplace transform of the conventional PERS can be given as
The corresponding natural frequency and the damping ratio are expressed as

Comparing equations (5) and (6) and equations (10) and (11), it can be seen that the frequency responses of the two systems are almost equal, but the damping ratio of the conventional PERS is much smaller than the system with regeneration because the leakage coefficient is usually much smaller than the flow pressure coefficient of the throttle. It means that the conventional PERS is more prone to oscillation. In addition, the speed response of the hydraulic motor is slower than the displacement response of the spool, resulting in further worsening of the dynamic performance.
In conventional PERS, the braking torque is provided by the regeneration device. Thus, the maximum electromagnetic torque of the generator is designed as

where P1max denotes the maximum pressure in the loaded chamber, Jt is the total equivalent moment of inertia, and αmax denotes the maximum braking deceleration. It can be seen that the electromagnetic torque of the generator should be sufficiently large to hold the load. Moreover, the loaded pressure often varies in practical operation as shown in Figure 3. Therefore, in fact, the required capacity of the generator is usually much larger than the rating value.

caption.p: Practical pressure in the large chamber of cylinder.

sec.title: Principle
sec.p: To overcome the shortcomings of the conventional PERS, a novel PERS with compound configuration is developed as shown in Figure 4. This system combines the throttle and the regeneration device together to decouple the functions of velocity control and energy regeneration. Its basic idea is to govern the cylinder velocity by adjusting the opening of the throttle and regenerate the potential energy by controlling the electromagnetic torque of the generator. In the compound PERS, the outlet flow of the throttle is resisted by the regeneration device instead of being connected to the oil tank directly as in the system without regeneration. Thus, a good control performance is achieved through throttle governing while potential energy regeneration is realized. Furthermore, the capacity of the regenerator can be reduced, as the extra recoverable energy is absorbed by the throttle.

However, with the use of throttle, a part of the potential energy of the compound PERS will be lost in contrast to the conventional PERS, and hence, keeping the lost energy at an acceptable level is a critical problem, which is strongly related to the control strategy that should be well designed.

sec.title: Control strategy
sec.p: There are three control strategy candidates for the generator in the compound PERS. The first one is the constant control where the generator provides a fixed electromagnetic torque. The constant torque should be relatively small to ensure normal operation for light load, and then the energy dissipation in the throttle will be large when the load is heavy. It means that the first strategy is not capable of load adapting. Therefore, although this strategy is simple and does not require feedback, it is almost unacceptable due to its low average-efficiency compared with the other two strategies.
The second strategy is the direct load compensation control where the torque command of the generator is calculated by subtracting a constant pressure drop from the loaded pressure as
where ΔP0 is the predetermined pressure drop over the throttle.
The third strategy is the pressure drop feedback control where negative feedback is employed to obtain the torque command that can be given as
where K is the amplification gain, and ΔP is the practical pressure drop over the throttle and can be expressed as
where P2 is the pressure in the inlet chamber of the hydraulic motor.

It can be seen that the second and the third strategies have the same control idea, where the pressure drop over the throttle is kept almost constant through adapting the regenerative torque to the loaded pressure. But as two different realizing approaches of the same idea, their characteristics should be investigated and compared with each other.

sec.title: Flow characteristic analysis
sec.p: This section analyzes the flow characteristics of the compound PERS with the second and third strategies, respectively. The flow equation of the throttle shown in Figure 4 can be written as
The pressure dynamics of the inlet chamber of the hydraulic motor is expressed as
where V2 is the volume of the chamber and C2 is the corresponding leakage coefficient.
The dynamic equation of the rotor of the regeneration device is given as
where Bm is the viscous friction coefficient, and Tf is the Coulomb friction torque.

To obtain the frequency response models, it also necessary to take the Laplace transform of the differential equations. By solving the equation sets, the flow rate Qt(s) can be expressed as a function of variables P1(s) and x(s), that is
where
When the second strategy is applied, the coefficients of the transfer functions are developed as
When the third strategy is applied, the coefficients of the transfer functions are developed as

It can be observed that the form of equation (19) is similar to the standard form of the flow rate expression through a throttle in the system without regeneration as expressed in equation (3). The transfer functions Gq(s) and Gp(s) can be considered as equivalents of the coefficients Kq and Kp. By analyzing the expressions, some conclusions can be drawn as follows:

list-item.p: The transfer function Gp(s) denotes the dynamic relationship between the flow rate Qt(s) and the load pressure P1(s). According to the final value theorem of the Laplace transform theory, the steady error of Gp(s) with step input is given by

By substituting the expressions of a0 and c0 into equation (34) and neglecting the viscous coefficient Bm, eq is equal to zero in the system with the second strategy and to KpDm(2πK+Dm)−1 with the third strategy. It can be seen that the flow rate Qt(s) has no relationship with the load pressure P1(s) in steady state, in the system with the second strategy. With the third strategy, although there is a steady error between the actual pressure drop over the throttle and the given value, the error can be relatively small by taking a proper value of K. Therefore, both the strategies are capable of load pressure compensation.

The natural frequency of the flow rate Qt(s) can be expressed as a0. According to the corresponding expressions of a0, the frequency response in the system with the third strategy is higher than that with the second strategy. The ideal state is that the transfer functions are totally equivalent to the proportional gains.

The damping ratio of the flow rate Qt(s) can be expressed as a1/2a0. According to the corresponding expressions of a0 and a1, the steady error can be reduced and the frequency response can be improved by properly increasing the amplification gain K in the system with the third strategy. However, it cannot be increased unlimitedly, as too large a value will produce an unfavorable influence on the system stability.

sec.title: Parameters
sec.p: There are several critical parameters of the compound PERS that should be taken into account in the design procedure. The product of the displacement and the maximum rotational speed of the hydraulic motor should be equal to the maximum flow rate. To avoid much energy lost in the throttle, the given pressure drop over the throttle is set with a small value. The maximum electromagnetic torque that denotes the capacity of the generator is designed as

where P1ave is the average pressure in the large chamber of the hydraulic cylinder. When the output torque of the generator is equal to the maximum value and saturated, the throttle is used to consume the extra energy. The amplification gain K is designed with frequency domain analysis, and then validated and adjusted through simulation and experiment.

sec.title: Simulation
sec.p: Nonlinear simulation is carried out using the AMEsim software to preliminarily evaluate the performance of the designed scheme and strategies. The simulation model and parameters are based on an experimental platform for hybrid excavators as described in detail in the next section. Figure 5 shows the developed simulation model, which is mainly composed of the hydraulic system, the vector-controlled generator, the super capacitor, and the controller. It can be seen that the auxiliary valves, the electrical dynamics, and the rod side circuit of the cylinder are also considered in the simulation.

caption.p: Developed simulation model based on the AMEsim software.

sec.p: For comparisons, the simulation investigates the four systems as follows: (a) the throttle-governing system without regeneration, (b) the conventional PERS, (c) the compound PERS with the second control strategy, and (d) the compound PERS with the third control strategy.

Figure 6 shows the cylinder velocity responses with the same input commands. As we can see, system (a) is the most stable while system (b) has the most serious oscillation. Both systems (c) and (d) are close to system (a), and system (d) is a little better than system (c).

caption.p: Velocity responses of the hydraulic cylinder: (a) throttle-governing system, (b) conventional PERS, (c) compound PERS with the second strategy, and (d) compound PERS with the third strategy.

sec.p: Antidisturbance capability is another important aspect, for an excavator often suffers drastic changes of load. Figure 7 shows the velocity variations when the load gravity is reduced by 40% at 3 s and recovered at 8 s. It can be observed that the results of systems (a) and (d) are much better than the results of systems (b) and (c). In fact, the velocity variation of system (d) is even smaller than system (a).

caption.p: Velocity variations under load changes: (a) throttle-governing system, (b) conventional PERS, (c) compound PERS with the second strategy, and (d) compound PERS with the third strategy.

sec.p: As can be seen, the simulation results illustrate that the compound PERS has better dynamic performance than the conventional PERS, and the third control strategy is the optimal strategy. The results are in accordance with the mathematical analysis.

sec.title: Experiment
sec.p: As shown in Figure 8, an experimental platform is built to research the boom PERS for a 7 ton hybrid excavator. The piston diameter and the rod diameter of the boom cylinder are 0.115 and 0.065 m, respectively. The oil source can maximally supply 0.12 m3 hydraulic oil per minute with a maximum pressure of 31.5 MPa. The proportional valve is used as the governing throttle of which the rating flow rate is 1.6 × 10−3 m3/s and the rating pressure drop is 3.5 MPa. An axial piston hydraulic motor and a permanent magnet synchronous generator are applied to the platform due to their high efficiency and power density. The displacement of the hydraulic motor is 5.5 × 10−5 m3. The generator has a rating speed of 220 rad/s and a rating torque of 100 N m. The energy storage device is a super capacitor with capacity 12.5 F, and the nominal voltage is 400 V. A DS1104 digital signal processing card is used as the controller where the control strategies are executed.

There are also some instruments employed to detect the required variables in real time. A displacement sensor is used to measure the boom velocity; pressure sensors are used to measure the pressure in the bottom chamber of the cylinder and the inlet chamber of the hydraulic motor; flowmeters are used to measure the flow rates; torque and speed sensors are used to detect the corresponding values of the generator; voltage and current sensors are used to measure the direct current (DC) link voltage and current of the super capacitor. The output of the displacement sensor is connected to the encoder interface of DS1104, and the other outputs are connected to the analog to digital (AD) interfaces. The sampling time of all the measurements is 0.001 s.

According to the analytical and simulated results, the compound PERS with the third control strategy is the most promising approach. Hence, experiments under different parameter conditions are carried out to validate and test this system. Figure 9 shows the velocities of the cylinder, the pressure drops over the throttle, and the electromagnetic torques of the generator when the amplification gain K is equal to 10, 30, and 50 N m/MPa, respectively. It can be observed that with the increase of K, the practical pressure drop is closer to the given value which is equal to 2 MPa in this group of experiments, and the regenerated power also becomes larger. Figure 10 presents the results when the given pressure drop ΔP0 is equal to 1.5, 2.0, and 2.5 MPa, respectively, and K is equal to 30 N m/MPa. It can be seen that with the decrease of ΔP0, the practical pressure drop as well as the lost energy is reduced. Therefore, increasing K and decreasing ΔP0 are beneficial to the energy regeneration efficiency. However, it also can be seen that the peak values of pressure and torque become larger with increased K and decreased ΔP0, which are unfavorable to the system. For the studied experimental platform, K = 30 N m/MPa and ΔP0 = 2 MPa are considered as acceptable.

caption.p: Experimental results under different amplification gains (a: 10 N m/MPa; b: 30 N m/MPa; c: 50 N m/MPa).
Experimental results under different given pressure drops (a: 1.5 MPa; b: 2.0 MPa; c: 2.5 MPa).

sec.p: The corresponding efficiencies of the two groups of experiments are shown in Figures 11 and 12 where ηsys, ηreg, and ηtot denote the hydraulic system efficiency, the regeneration device efficiency, and the total efficiency, respectively, and are defined as

caption.p: Efficiencies under different given pressure drops.

sec.p: where Q1 is the flow rate out of the large chamber of the cylinder, Q2 is the flow rate out of the inlet chamber of the hydraulic motor, Ud and Id are the voltage and charging current of the super capacitor, respectively. In practical application, Q1 and Q2 are almost equal to each other.

As shown in Figures l1 and 12, the maximum total efficiency reaches about 0.49, and further improvement is expected through optimization. It can be observed that the total efficiency as well as the hydraulic system efficiency can be enhanced with the increase of K and the decrease of ΔP0, In addition, the regeneration device efficiency has little relationship with the two parameters.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: A compound PERS for HHE is developed to overcome the disadvantages of the conventional PERS by modeling through simulation and finally through experimental validation. The results are summarized as follows.

list-item.p: The developed compound PERS combines a regeneration device and a throttle together, which are used to regenerate the potential energy and govern the cylinder velocity, respectively. The cylinder control performance can be improved, and the regenerator capacity can be reduced using the compound PERS.

Three control strategies are proposed, including the constant control, the direct load compensation control, and the pressure drop feedback control. It is analyzed that the average regeneration efficiency of the first strategy is low, and the third strategy has a better dynamic performance than the second strategy, according to mathematical analysis as well as nonlinear simulations. Thus, the third strategy is the optimal choice.

The effects of two critical parameters are investigated. The total efficiencies are 32.9%, 45.6%, and 48.6% when the amplification gain is equal to 10, 30, and 50 N m/MPa, respectively. The total efficiencies are 42.1%, 45.6%, and 48.7% when the given pressure drop is 2.5, 2.0, and 1.5 MPa, respectively. Therefore, properly increasing the amplification gain and decreasing the given pressure drop are beneficial to the regeneration efficiency.

sec.p: Further researches will be concentrated on managing the regenerated energy and applying the proposed compound PERS to practical machines.
